title: 1940 PGA Championship
text:
The 1940 PGA Championship was the 23rd <a href="PGA%20Championship">PGA Championship</a>, held August 26 to September 2 at <a href="Hershey%20Country%20Club">Hershey Country Club</a> in <a href="Hershey%2C%20Pennsylvania">Hershey, Pennsylvania</a>, east of <a href="Harrisburg%2C%20Pennsylvania">Harrisburg</a>. Then a <a href="match%20play">match play</a> championship, <a href="Byron%20Nelson">Byron Nelson</a> won his first PGA Championship, defeating <a href="Sam%20Snead">Sam Snead</a> 1 up in the 36-hole final. It was the third of Nelson's five <a href="Men%27s%20major%20golf%20championships">major</a> titles; he won the PGA Championship again in <a href="1945%20PGA%20Championship">1945</a>. From 1939 to 1945, Nelson made five of the six finals, missing only in <a href="1942%20PGA%20Championship">1942</a> (not held in 1943). 
Defending champion and host professional <a href="Henry%20Picard">Henry Picard</a> lost in the third round to <a href="Gene%20Sarazen">Gene Sarazen</a>. Also out in the third round was five-time champion <a href="Walter%20Hagen">Walter Hagen</a>, age 47, in his last PGA Championship match. He gained his last win in the second round over <a href="Vic%20Ghezzi">Vic Ghezzi</a>, the champion the following year in <a href="1941%20PGA%20Championship">1941</a>. Hagen ended his career with a 40–10 () match record in the event. He played one last time at age 49 in the qualifier in <a href="1942%20PGA%20Championship">1942</a>, but did not advance to match play.
Heavy rains on Saturday stopped play halfway through the semifinals which were completed on Sunday; the final round was pushed back to Monday, which was <a href="Labor%20Day">Labor Day</a>.
<a href="Dick%20Metz">Dick Metz</a> was the medalist in the stroke play qualifier at 140 (−6); he lost 2 & 1 in the third round to Nelson. Two-time champion <a href="Denny%20Shute">Denny Shute</a> qualified at 151, but was rushed to a local hospital for an emergency <a href="appendectomy">appendectomy</a> that night.
